contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a rhetorical question that a father would ask to discipline his son. Alternate translation: "You should know that what you have done is wrong." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why have you done this or that?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The purpose of this question is to introduce the information that Nathan wants to tell Bathsheba. Alternate translation: "You do not seem to have heard ... it." or "Have you heard ... it?" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have you not heard ... it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The purpose of this question was to remind David of what he had promised Bathsheba. Alternate translation: "you swore to your servant ... throne." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: did you not swear to your servant ... throne?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bathsheba was to use a question so David would pay attention. Alternate translation: "So then, Adonijah should not be reigning." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why then is Adonijah reigning?

contextId.occurrenceNote: King Solomon was angered by his mother's request. Alternate translation: "You are wrong to ask ... Adonijah! This is the same as asking the kingdom for him also ... Zeruiah!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why do you ask ... Adonijah? Why do you not ask the kingdom for him also ... Zeruiah?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon is reminding Shimei of what Shimei had promised. Alternate translation: "You know very well that I made you swear ... saying, 'Know ... die'!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Did I not make you swear ... saying, 'Know ... die'?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Solomon is asking for an answer or 2) Alternate translation: "You have done wrong by breaking your oath ... you." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why then have you not kept your oath ... you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon asks a question to emphasize that he knows that no one can judge. Alternate translation: "No one is able to judge this great people of yours." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: For who is able to judge this great people of yours?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings of this question are 1) Solomon is asking a real question and expecting an answer or 2) the question is rhetorical and Solomon is emphasizing that God is too big and mighty to live on earth. Alternate translation: "But it surely cannot be that God will actually live on the earth!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: But will God actually live on the earth?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hiram is rebuking Solomon. This questions can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "These cities that you have given me are good for nothing." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What cities are these which you have given me, my brother?

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Share" here is a metonym meaning a part, involvement, or interest. This question can be translated as a simple statement. Alternate translation: "We will have no part in the family of David." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: What share do we have in David?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question shows that Ahijah knew she was disguised. Alternate translation: "Stop pretending to be someone else; I know who you are." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why do you pretend to be someone you are not?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is used to either inform or remind the readers that the information about Abijah is in this other book. See how you translated this in [1 Kings 14:29](../14/29.md). This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "they are written in the book of the events of the kings of Judah." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: are they not written in the book of the events of the kings of Judah?

This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. See how you translated this in [1 Kings 15:31](../15/31.md). Alternate translation: "they are written in the book of the events of the kings of Israel." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: are they not written ... kings of Israel?

This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. See how you translated a similar phrase concerning Judah in [1 Kings 14:29](../14/29.md). Alternate translation: "they are written in the book of the events of the kings of Israel." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is used to either inform or remind the readers that the information about Omri is in this other book. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. See how you translated this in [1 Kings 15:31](../15/31.md). Alternate translation: "they are written in the book of the events of the kings of Israel." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: are they not written in the book of the events of the kings of Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Elijah is truly asking a question. Alternate translation: "why would you cause the widow with whom I am staying to suffer even more by killing her son" or 2) Elijah uses a question to express how sad he is. Alternate translation: "surely, you would not cause the widow with whom I am staying to suffer even more by killing her son" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: have you also brought disaster on the widow with whom I am staying, by killing her son?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Obadiah asks this question to emphasize the danger to himself because of King Ahab's anger at Elijah. Alternate translation: "I have not wronged you ... for him to kill me." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How have I sinned ... for him to kill me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ahab asks the question for emphasis to be certain about Elijah's identity. Alternate translation: "So here you are. You are the troublemaker of Israel!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is it you? You are the one who brings trouble to Israel!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elijah asks this question to urge the people to make a decision. This question can be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "You have been indecisive for long enough." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How long will you keep changing your mind?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke Elijah and to remind him of his duty. Alternate translation: "This is not where you should be, Elijah." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What are you doing here, Elijah?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to emphasize the size and strength of Ben Hadad's army. Alternate translation: "Look at this great army." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have you seen this great army?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ahab asks this question to express surprise. Alternate translation: "I am surprised that he is still alive!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is he still alive?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jezebel uses this negative rhetorical question to rebuke Ahab. It can be translated as a positive statement. Alternate translation: "You still rule the kingdom of Israel!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do you not still rule the kingdom of Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to scold Ahab. Alternate translation: "You have killed Naboth and stolen his vineyard!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have you killed and also taken possession?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ahab uses this question to express anger toward Elijah. That Elijah "found" Ahab likely refers to Elijah discovering Ahab's actions, not to finding his physical location. Alternate translation: "You have found me, my enemy!" or "You have discovered what I have done, my enemy!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Have you found me, my enemy?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God uses this question to show Elijah that Ahab's sorrow is genuine. Alternate translation: "I have seen how Ahab humbles himself before me." or "Look at how Ahab humbles himself before me." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do you see how Ahab humbles himself before me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ahab asks this question to emphasize that they should have already recaptured Ramoth Gilead. Alternate translation: "Ramoth Gilead is ours, but we have done nothing yet to take it from the hand of the king of Aram." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do you know that Ramoth Gilead is ours, but that we are doing nothing to take it from the hand of the king of Aram?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ahab asks this question out of frustration to rebuke Micaiah. Alternate translation: "Many times I have required ... in the name of Yahweh." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How many times must I require ... in the name of Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ahab asks this question to emphasize that he had spoken the truth about Micaiah. Alternate translation: "I told you ... but only disaster!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Did I not tell you ... but only disaster?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zedekiah asks this sarcastic question to insult and rebuke Micaiah. Alternate translation: "Do not think that Yahweh's Spirit left me to speak to you!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Which way did the Spirit of Yahweh take to go from me to speak to you?
